thread.title: North Carolina billboard turns heads, proclaiming 'Real men provide'
thread.title_full: North Carolina billboard turns heads, proclaiming 'Real men provide'

author: Kalhan Rosenblatt
title: North Carolina billboard turns heads, proclaiming 'Real men provide'
text:
North Carolina billboard turns heads, proclaiming 'Real men provide' NBC News 4 hrs ago Kalhan Rosenblatt © A billboard in Greensboro, North Carolina. Image: A billboard in Greensboro, North Carolina A billboard in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, will be at the heart of a protest on Sunday after some in the community took offense to the seven-word sentence.
"Real men provide, real women appreciate it," it reads.
The billboard is owned by Whiteheart Outdoor Advertising, according to the Triad-City Beat , but the company is not sponsoring the message. President Bill Whiteheart told the paper that the person who bought the advertisement space will be coming forward with a statement "in the future."
Whiteheart Outdoor Advertising did not immediately return a request for comment made by NBC News.
Meanwhile, the Whiteheart Outdoor Advertising Facebook page has become inundated with people commenting, calling the sign "misogynistic" and "disgusting."
Molly Grace, owner of a local boutique called Kleur, decided to plan a rally around the billboard on Sunday to protest its message. Grace said the protest isn't politically motivated, but instead is intended to start a discussion.
Related: Merriam-Webster Tweet Corrects Conway's Definition of Feminism
© Molly Grace is organizing a protest against a billboard in Winston-Salem, North Carolina. Image: Molly Grace is organizing a protest against a billboard in Greensboro "I take it also as a very deliberate jab at women who demand equality and demand to be seen as equals and those who are vocal," Grace told NBC News affiliate WXII News 12 . "So to me it's also a very blatant statement about wanting to silence women and tell them to just accept the way things are."
Sunday's protest is expecting 128 people, but 444 have said they're interested in attending, according to the Facebook page.
Grace did not immediately respond to NBC News' request for comment.
